comments.commentBody: Trump only has himself to blame. An admitted non-intellect, he won't even take advice or change for the better. He'll be a one man administration, he thinks. And while his success and following recalls Reagan, he nowhere has the class or looks, or clarity of purpose. More and more, Trump is looking like a man with a private grudge to set straight rather than a man asking for the priviledge of serving the American people. So if Clinton and Sanders can make peace, and maybe a ticket, then the election should go to the Democrats and 4 more years of the status quo, give or take. Maybe the best thing given the field.

A vote for Cruz will leave this country is the same destruction mode that they have placed us for decades. Cruz is a junior Senator who has done nothing except to help shut down our government which cost us a lot of money. He has done nothing except to collect his paycheck. Trump is the only candidate that brought up the subject of illegal immigration, NATO, our lost jobs and the very bad deals that were made while Cruz was in the Senate. Vote for Trump and we can have hope that our country will be good again.

Please, please, please let Trump be the candidate! Hilary will beat him like a drum in November. It will make the Goldwater landslide look like a minor crumbling.

And Cruz is just scary. His positions are so far right it is hard to even comprehend them. But he has a better chance to win in November if only because some of his demographic will vote for him to get the 'first Hispanic president'... that scares me a lot..

The Republicans need to take a lesson from the Democrats. The Democratic party has it rigged so that the party bosses' favorite (Hillary) cannot possibly lose. Look for a change in the GOP bylaws the next time around.

The really good news is that the Republican Party has reached a breaking point, and a good solid loss this year will go a long way to causing fiscally conservative  individuals the formulate a better party. The current crop of religious fanatics who want government to support their religious views need to be drummed out of the renewed party.

Who is worse between Trump and Cruz?

Cruz will do what he thinks is best for America. It will often be misguided and way too conservative for the mainstream, but his narcissism and commitment to being reelected will help.

Trump will do what's best for Trump.

replies.commentBody:
Yes. This is why we need Ranked Preference Voting in primary elections.

Delegates are a hold-over from a time before secure encrypted telecommunications. They need to send human messengers to the conventions for to prevent any shenanigans with interlopers intercepting and changing written communications.

And the contested/brokered convention process is a hold-over from a time before computers that could instantly retally the ranked-preference ballots after your first choice drops out.

Just imaging how this GOP primary would have gone differently if people could vote for who they truly wanted without having to worry about "a vote for X is a vote for Y!" And think of the people who voted for Fiorina, Carson, Bush, or Rubio and who's votes went up in smoke when their candidate dropped out. They can't revote.

It would be better if we could rank the candidates from most favored to least favored. The top choice of the candidates remaining in the race is who a given ballot counts towards. Hours before the convention like-minded candidates would hold a little pow-wow to discus how vote might shift in different scenarios and decide who should remain in the race. And if there is no candidate with a majority by the convention, then party could systematically remove the lowest scoring candidate, have the computer retally according the the new criteria, and rinse-and-repeat until a victor emerges.

If we had something like Trump would be ancient history by now.
Heck, give us Ranked Preference in the primary as well.  We could actually have viable third-party candidates without fear of vote-splitting.

comments.commentBody:
In Republican-Land, there is no good candidate. Even a broad base of Republicans are turned off by Cruz. Look at how much support he has (not) gotten from his Senate co-workers. Nobody in the Republican party who has 1/4 of a brain wants Cruz to be the front-runner, and nobody wants Trump either. Kasich merely appears to be a reasonable candidate but he's not presidential material either. Astonishing that they can go from more than 17 candidates to the worst out of the entire bunch.

Not to worry, even if it's Cruz vs. whoever is the Democrat nominee. The presidential electorate is gradually tilting toward the left. Unless the Republican party cleans up its act, they may never take the White House again.

This process takes too long. States keep moving their primaries earlier and earlier to try to increase their prestige and significance. From announcement to election is nearly a year-and-half. That's too much for something that happens every four years.

I'd like for this to be done over the course of five consecutive Tuesdays, in five rounds of ten states each, sometime in mid-to-late summer. The week in between votes would be enough time for debates and for some candidates to top out. Then they have their conventions a week later, and still have a few months for general election campaigning.

The schedule should be arranged so that each round involves roughly the same number of votes and delegates by including a mix of large, medium, and small states (and maybe one of the islands and DC). Take the five larges states as a groups and distribute them among the five weeks; then do the same with the next largest five; and so on. This could be done by random drawing. But think the better way would be to order them inversely to how well that party did in the previous general election. Republican would do arrange the groups for five from bluest to reddest, Democrats from reddest to bluest. This would deliberately introduce a slight bias in favor of more moderate candidates. Red-state Republican votes are not the same as blue-state Republicans. This would help address the extreme polarization that is tearing this country apart.

Just an idea. We need to somehow cleanup this mess.
It seems unlikely that a theocrat can win the general election. That leaves Trump if the Republicans are serious about the presidency.

replies.commentBody:
"he is eminently beatable"

Here's where you are wrong. Those aggrieved (and populist) Sanders supporters will move to the Trump camp in the general election.

comments.commentBody:
Rooting for Trump, to become nominee, because :
1) He is much less scary that Cruz
2) He is eminently beatable in November, with the added bonus of the Democrats regaining control of at least the Senate.

The current Republican party deserves to be dismantled since it has been a damaging and regressive factor as far as the US as whole.

To me it is Cruz, not Trump, whose ideas are truly frightening. Returning America to the gold standard? Eliminating the income tax and replacing it with a national sales tax (I know he does not use that term, but that is the effect of his proposal)? Eliminate Obamacare and replace it with a race-to-the-bottom approach of interstate sale of health insurance (something not allowed for car or homeowners insurance)? Military intervention in Syria and Iraq? Religious rhetoric that sends shivers down my spine?

So to me the choice is "Stop Cruz" by voting for Trump. And Trump is at least honest about the faults of Citizens United.

replies.commentBody: From US Census.gov, Trump has potential in Indiana manufacture shipments is a big part of their economy and lower college education as % of population wrt Missouri and Wisconsin.  If Trump wins Indiana, it could be the biggest boost.

comments.commentBody:
I see Cruz winning Indiana. He has done well in the Midwest, winning Wisconsin and Iowa and finishing second in Michigan, Illinois and Minnesota. Indiana is more conservative than all of those states. Cruz will probably get the endorsements of Govs. Pence and Daniels (not sure that he'd want Gov. Pence's endorsement, as I understand that he's rather unpopular with Hoosiers these days, but from what I know Gov. Daniels is still quite popular). One thing to watch for is Kasich possibly getting significant support in east-Indiana near the Ohio border, which could swing the outcome to any of the three candidates. But if Cruz pulls it off, and if Trump needs Indiana for a delegate majority, then bye-bye delegate majority, hello contested convention, and bye-bye Trump as the Republican nominee.

On the Democratic side, I see Sanders winning Indiana. He's well-positioned to win all 4 states which vote in May, so this puts at least some pressure on Clinton to clean up in the Northeast the second half of this month if she wants to avoid Armageddon in California on June 7.
Look, if Trump can really get out the KKK and Stormfront vote, his possibilities are endless. Heil Trump!

replies.commentBody:
"This almost guarantees Cruz the nomination. So it really is upsetting. I don't know why everyone isn't as upset as I am."

Karen, so many people have been repelled by Trump's admittedly inflammatory rhetoric that they haven't figured out that most of his policy positions are actually more moderate than those of Cruz. Heck, some of his positions (on trade and foreign policy, for instance) would put him to the left of Hillary.
Thank you Rick, I feel less alone.

comments.commentBody: People shouldn't read too much into what happended in Wisconsin. GOP voters there are easily manipulated via TV ads and radio talk shows. Probably a lot more so than in most of the remaining battlegounds. Wisconsin's progressive history would favor Sanders but Democrats are still unlikely to stay home if Hillary is the nominee. Members of the sizable Indpendent bloc are probably going to pick the least radical of any choice between the eventual nominees, which is probably why Kasich did well in areas where GOP moderates can still be found.

Well, I'm a Democrat so I don't get to vote in the Republican primary ... but if I were able to, I don't know what I'd do.

The question of whether Cruz or Trump is worse for America, or the GOP is s vexing question, even if you are a real GOP voter. Right now lots of Republicans are asking themselves which one they want to see run and lose the general election. That's pretty terrible.

A vote for Kasich would seem a safe and responsible one, but it seems most unlikely he can be the candidate, even coming into a divided convention with no-one holding a majority. A vote for Kasich seems to me to end up empowering a delegate to make their choice between Cruz or Trump. It sends some message of "moderation" ... not much more.

People in New York city sure don't like Cruz ... my sense is that Trump is going to take the Republican vote in New York.

But New York isn't going to vote for Trump or Cruz in the general. I don't see either of these men winning the presidency ... what are Republicans thinking?

replies.commentBody:

Since more than half of Americans claim they would never vote for someone who has had their buttocks hair surgically grafted onti their head as a replacement hair transplant for their thinning locks, the model docks Trump a few points for this. hope this helps.
Love,
A Fearless Truthteller

comments.commentBody:
Nate,
Do any of the demographic models consider transplants? For example, does Indiana have a high percentage of Ohioans and with other states do you ever see transplants swaying the traditional voting patterns?

replies.commentBody: That's right Joe; 54 out of 71 are unpledged. The GOP establishment is thanking its lucky stars for that this year, since Trump is leading in the polling there.

comments.commentBody: I thought that most of Pennsylvania's delegates are unpledged and don't have to vote for the winner of the state.

Goodness Gracious, Great Balls of Fire...It's déjà vue all over again!

In 2012 the GOP front-runner had to stare down a concerted effort within his own party attempting to un-seat his lead and defeat his campaign before the convention.

Here in 2016 the GOP front-runner is staring down a concerted effort within his own party attempting to un-seat his lead and defeat his campaign before the convention.

Beginning to look a lot like...the GOP leadership should either start listening to their constituents or boot these out to go off on their own and find a new set of constituents with whom they can actually lead rather than constantly feud.

Now really, how can one not like a political hyperbole which implies so strongly that the losing performance in the lost state of Wisconsin is a solid example of likely performance in the stronger states of the Northeast?

Well, sure he could there and why not.  He's got $, orange tanning cream and unlimited crazy voter that adore his brand of hubris.  Without the requisite votes the world would be denied the greatest political debacle in the history of the world.  A spectacle destined to rewrite ideas of politics forever.  A US Presidential election when the Republican candidate was unable to win a single state or get a single electoral college vote.  An unlikely return to a single party system for two generations.

replies.commentBody: I think a Baffon (note the capitalization) is a person who considers himself intelligent but cannot spell words in his native language, even when phonetics would suggest the word is misspelled.

comments.commentBody: Trump is a Baffon My seventh grader knows more about the Mideast Sunni Shiite Iran Alawite Syria etc He makes it up as he goes and the supposed fifth estate just ignores it as long as their advertising rates stay high.  He is a true tale of an idiot full of sound and fury.

replies.commentBody: What is a "real person", and in what sense is Donald Trump, a friendless, gilded billionaire witha staff of many servants and butlers, this Daddy's Boy who was given control of his company as a graduation present for the difficult achievement of graduating from Fordham, this draft-dodger, this overfed Trust-fund baby with orange skin and a fake hairpiece, one? I'll be waiting.

comments.commentBody:
I hope Trump gets the nomination. For one, he is still the only real person running, two, his win could help drive the Republican Party off a cliff, once and for all, forcing them to either become extinct or reform as something far less radical (the Whigs went away, then the Republicans, under Lincoln tried to burn the country down in response to South's actions), so that thinking may need a re-boot.

But his win will drive them crazy....a positive!

I do not see how Mr. Cruz can unify Repub voters. He can only be the "anyone but Trump" lesser of two extraordinarily unqualified and dangerous candidates in the minds of Republican voters. Subtract out the die hards, immersed in their faux realities (fed by anger and fear in the case of Trump and evangelical religion in the case of Cruz) and you are left with a vast majority of voters in both parties who will either not vote (doubtful) or vote Democratic in the general election. I want the GOP to survive but it must first wake up from its prolonged mental illness.

replies.commentBody: Well, I don't think Bernie has 'no path to the nomination.' He is faring quite well, and only a little more than 240 delegates behind Hillary. He has won 6 of 7 elections comng into today. That's manageable. Don't buy the mainstream media's wholesale write-off of Bernie's viability.

Here is some of the unfairness that has dogged Trump that has me upset and has given us Cruz.
The bar rooms brawls at his rallies result from a flood of protesters coming to the rallies and in all honestly, they are looking to stop the rally. Had they gone to Cruz rallies they would have gotten into fights. Had they gone to Christie rallies, and behaved like idiots, they would have gotten into fights. They went to Trump rallies, who is honestly, among the Republican candidates, the only one wanting to hold up the social safety net, increase entitlements, and spread the wealth among the little guy. The only one who is anti war. Who is against big oil. The protesters were egged on by the press to damage Trump. They did. Why didn't the press egg them on to go to Cruz rallies and dispense with his candidacy?
Hliary crushes bernie in all online betting markets dealing with NY primary (predict it,intrade)

comments.commentBody:
In my state of current residence, Mr. Trump won overwhelmingly ... except in the two population centers where diversity existed ---Columbia and Greenville. Diverse populations do not take to Mr. Trump's Xenophobic view of the World, and we don't like walls, how-some-ever built or who pays for it. Campaign rally bar room brawls and screeching at everyone who is different does not thrill us either.
Nope, polls are beginning to tell a different story of Mr. Trump reception at the doorstep of many Americans. The G.O.P. would be well advised to look before leaping.

replies.commentBody: But the vote won't split 3 ways and leave Trump with a 45% plurality. If anything, it'll be Hillary with the 45% plurality. Trump and Cruz won't be taking too many votes from the left.

Trump can't do a third party run.  He can't finance it.  It's quixotic.  He's actually a pretty sensible person who has a history of making reasonable decisions; not a quixotic person.  I can see him throwing his support behind Clinton, but I doubt it will help.
Cruz is delusional thinking he can win

comments.commentBody: This is far better than the pundits who believe winning Wisconsin was the start of Cruz's path to victory, and more nonsense. It might be best for Hilary if Cruz is given the nomination at the convention and Trump launches a third party campaign. Despite a recent claim I saw somewhere that it is unlikely that the Republican party will disappear over the splits and policies, the point is that the name of the party does not have to disappear a party into a new party or a split that changes the politics in the way the South has done to the Republicans. The Republicans, in name or with a new one, can rid itself of the reactionary South, and create a new party.
